instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.C1950: What is C1950? Capacitor between PP3V42_G3H & ground on pin 8 of U1950 on 2013-2015 Macbook Pros & Airs that often corrodes. When corroded, pin 8 on U1950 will be damaged, which will prevent machine from booting and cause PM_SLP_S4_L to pulse. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 3 fan spins then shuts off after 1 second
threads.message:
This board initially was just a no backlight issue and there was liquid damage around the entire lcd connector area as well as the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>. I replaced all the components in those areas and after all this now the fan does the usual on and off fan spin 3 times but after about 1 second the fan stops spinning. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.6v and once the fan stops spinning o <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> rails are present.

There was also liquid damage to the JTAG connector which I removed. I thought the issue for this fan spin may have been because I found that Pins 30&34 of J6100 were bridged together but even after fixing that the issue remains.
<CAPACITOR>C5120</CAPACITOR> did not look good so I replaced it along with <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>. All the proper voltages are present on <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>
I replaced <CAPACITOR>C5003</CAPACITOR>/09 because they didn't look to well.
There was a little corrosion around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> so I put some flux and heated that area.
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and its area looks fine and I get 3v42 on <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> even when the fan stops spinning.

It is doing all of this with no external components plugged in.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 3 fan spins then shuts off after 1 second
threads.message:
I was looking around and I noticed L8304 was accidentally bridged to the ground pin of <CAPACITOR>C8315</CAPACITOR>. I don't know how L8304 being connected to ground could cause the s0 rails to shut off.

This thread can be closed.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 3 fan spins then shuts off after 1 second
threads.message:
I believe there is a current sensor that monitors  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> between its origin (<CHIP>U8300</CHIP>´s output) and the LCD.
It occurs right after the 3 rtc cycling because it's at this stage that Apple logo appears witch means when image and backlight are told to start.

So at the moment where lcd image is enabled <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> is high and tells <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> to release 3.3v at the output.
As soon as <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> outputs 3.3v the overcurrent caused by the short is detected and reported to the smc witch with some magic  stops S0 rails.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 3 fan spins then shuts off after 1 second
